title: Sacred and Profane Love: A Novel in Three Episodes
author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

quoteFirst: _--This morning I began to order my times of work, of going out with my gun, time of sleep, and time of diversion, viz., every morning I walked out with my gun for two or three hours, if it did not rain; then employed myself to work till about eleven o’clock; then eat what I had to live on; and from
quoteLast: I lay down to sleep, the weather being excessive hot; and then in the evening to work again. The working part of this day and of the next were wholly employed in making my table; for I was yet but a very sorry workman, though time and necessity made me a complete natural mechanic soon after, as I believe it would do any one else.
title: Robinson Crusoe
author: Defoe, Daniel, 1661?-1731; Wyeth, N. C. (Newell Convers), 1882-1945 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , in a bend to the left, S.E., where we go again left in N.E. by N. On the same side there is a tolerably well built little village on the shore.
title: Expedition to discover the sources of the White Nile, in the years 1840, 1841, Vol. 2 (of 2)
author: Werne, Ferdinand, 1800-1874; O'Reilly, Charles William [Translator]

quoteLast: See what the day will do.
title: A Medley of Weather Lore
author: Wright, M. E. S. [Compiler]

quoteFirst: “To-morrow I will order a conveyance of some sort, we will put on our smartest frocks and pay a round of calls from
quoteLast: . Bertie got a list from the club baboo. We will begin with the general’s wife, the commissioner’s wife, the padre’s wife, and so on.
title: Quicksands
author: Croker, B. M. (Bithia Mary), 1849?-1920

quoteFirst: From eleven to half past twelve he would put in a little gentle work. Lunch, unless there was a rush of business or Mr Waller happened to suffer from a spasm of conscientiousness, could be spun out from half past
quoteLast: . More work from two till half past three. From half past three till half past four tea in the tearoom, with a novel.
title: Psmith in the City
author: Wodehouse, P. G. (Pelham Grenville), 1881-1975

title: John Bull; Or, The Englishman's Fireside: A Comedy, in Five Acts

quoteFirst: There was one especially, a fat, heavy man, who would retire into the shadow of the wall and doze so comfortably during his two hours, that I have dropped pieces of plaster from my window at his very feet, without his observing it. By good luck, this fellow's watch was due from
quoteLast: upon the night which we had fixed upon for our enterprise.
title: The Exploits of Brigadier Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan, 1859-1930

quoteFirst: The Artillery Corps fired minute guns from the South Battery for an hour, and from
quoteLast: the shops throughout the town were closed.
title: Yarmouth Notes, 1830-1872. Collated from the File of the Norwich Mercury
author: Palmer, Frederick Danby

quoteFirst: Before we left Richmond, a gentleman told me, when I really was so exhausted that I could hardly stand, that 'three people of great fashion' were much offended by having been told, when they called last evening, that I was tired and not visible, then, but would be 'at home' from
quoteLast: next day! Another gentleman (no doubt of great fashion also) sent a letter to me two hours after I had gone to bed, preparatory to rising at four next morning, with instructions to the slave who brought it to knock me up and wait for an answer!
title: The Life of Charles Dickens, Vol. I-III, Complete
author: Forster, John, 1812-1876
